caption_text: In Fig. 5, substantial hydrogen is added at 600 C and the results are markedly different from those shown in the previous two figures. Both the olefin and benzene concentrations become very small within the first 2 s. The paraffin concentration increases rapidly due to hydrogenation.

caption_text: Figure 7 shows the result of adding hydrogen at 700 C to the same initial mixture as was used to generate Fig. 6. The benzenes rapidly hydrogenate while the naphthalenes do so more slowly. The aver- age carbon number of the naphthalene class stays nearly constant, indicating that the combination of benzenes and naphthalenes does not occur to a signifi- cant extent.
raw_window: Figure 7 shows the result of adding hydrogen at 700 C to the same initial mixture as was used to generate Fig. 6.
The benzenes rapidly hydrogenate while the naphthalenes do so more slowly.
The aver- age carbon number of the naphthalene class stays nearly constant, indicating that the combination of benzenes and naphthalenes does not occur to a signifi- cant extent.

caption_text: In Fig. 8, at 700 C with no hydrogen, the naphthalenes condense with themselves slightly and with the small amount of benzenes present. Some paraffin cracking does occur as is evidenced by the small amount of olefins formed. Figure 9 shows the result of adding hydrogen at 700 C to the same initial hydrocarbon mixture as was shown in Fig. 8.
raw_window: In Fig. 8, at 700 C with no hydrogen, the naphthalenes condense with themselves slightly and with the small amount of benzenes present.

Figure 9 shows the result of adding hydrogen at 700 C to the same initial hydrocarbon mixture as was shown in Fig. 8.

caption_text: In order to test the sensitivity of the model to the value of KEQ, the simulation shown in Fig. 7 was rerun using two larger values for the activation energy of the initiation reactions. Figure 10 shows that the value of this parameter does not affect the shape of the concentration profiles. Rather, it merely alters the time scale of the simulation.

Figures 3 5 show that increasing hydrogen concen- tration suppresses olefin formation and enhances paraffin cracking as the results of Brooks (1967) indicate.
raw_window: Compound class concentrations and average carbon numbers for initial composition 2 (paraffins and naphthalenes, see Table 3) with hydrogen concentration =0 mol/l at 700 C.
Figures 3 5 show that increasing hydrogen concen- tration suppresses olefin formation and enhances paraffin cracking as the results of Brooks (1967) indicate.

caption_text: In Fig. 4 very few paraffins are present and cracking does not occur to a significant extent in either the paraffins or olefins as can be seen from the curves of average carbon number. However, in Fig. 5 a larger concentration of paraffins is created and cracking reactions dominate the reaction se- quence after 1.6 s in both the olefins and paraffins. Prior to 1.6 s in Fig. 5, cracking reactions play a minor role since the paraffins concentration is low.
raw_window: In Fig. 4 very few paraffins are present and cracking does not occur to a significant extent in either the paraffins or olefins as can be seen from the curves of average carbon number.
However, in Fig. 5 a larger concentration of paraffins is created and cracking reactions dominate the reaction se- quence after 1.6 s in both the olefins and paraffins.
Prior to 1.6 s in Fig. 5, cracking reactions play a minor role since the paraffins concentration is low.

caption_text: The transition from addition reaction dominance to cracking reaction dominance is marked in Fig. 5 by the maxima in the curves of average carbon number for the olefins and paraffins. Rebick (1983) predicted that the presence of aro- maties would inhibit the cracking of paraffins while, conversely, paraffins would accelerate the conversion of aromatics. A comparison of Figs 5 and 9 bears out that prediction.
raw_window: The transition from addition reaction dominance to cracking reaction dominance is marked in Fig. 5 by the maxima in the curves of average carbon number for the olefins and paraffins.
Rebick (1983) predicted that the presence of aro- maties would inhibit the cracking of paraffins while, conversely, paraffins would accelerate the conversion of aromatics.
A comparison of Figs 5 and 9 bears out that prediction.

caption_text: Paraffin cracking is clearly shown in Fig. 5 but is absent in Fig. 9. Aromatics inhibit paraffin Compound class modeling of hydropyrolysis 2855 28 2.6 24 2.2 0 .0 ~ 2.0 C) a, 1.8 i 1.2 1.0 0.8 1.5 .4 .3 1.2 = 1.0 0 0.9 0.8 0.7 0.6 0 ~ 0.5 0.4 0.3 0.2 0.1 cracking because they depress the number of paraffin radicals in the mixture due to the superior resonance stabilization of aromatic radicals. caption_text: The classes are listed in Table I and include a variety of aliphatic, olefinie and aromatic groups. A more extensive list could be formulated; however, these classes are readily measur- able and include most of the molecular classes present in heavy oils.

caption_text: substituted naphthalene radical Compound class modeling of hydropyrolysis 2849 Tables I and 2 indicate that hydropyrolysis kinetics of heavy hydrocarbons can be formulated in a much simpler manner than a detailed mechanistic model. The most important simplification is the reduction of the number of components from several hundred in a hydrocarbon mixture to a number on the order of 10 in the compound class model.
raw_window: substituted naphthalene radical Compound class modeling of hydropyrolysis 2849 Tables I and 2 indicate that hydropyrolysis kinetics of heavy hydrocarbons can be formulated in a much simpler manner than a detailed mechanistic model.
The most important simplification is the reduction of the number of components from several hundred in a hydrocarbon mixture to a number on the order of 10 in the compound class model.
The current model can be run on a mini-computer (VAX 11/750) while full mechanistic models would require the use of super- computers.
table_reason: The caption ends after S1, which provides a clear description of the table content; S2 is a general statement about model performance, not part of the caption.

caption_text: The-temperature, hydrogen concentration, and initial hydrocarbon composition (see Table 3) were varied.
raw_window: The-temperature, hydrogen concentration, and initial hydrocarbon composition (see Table 3) were varied.
The numerical simulations were carried out with a VAX 11/750 computer.

Most runs simulated 10 s of real time but this was not feasible in all cases At the higher tem- peratures, especially with high hydrogen concentra- tions, the system of equations became quite stiff and required large amounts of computer time.
